titleInfo.title: Harold Adams and Louise Adams oral history interview

mods.abstract: Harold and Louise Adams discuss their courtship while they were both students at Nicholls State University in Thibodaux, and the earlier years of their marriage while they were both teachers. Harold discusses his career as an educator, which includes serving as a teacher and principal in Golden Meadow Public Schools and working for a federal education program. He also discusses education reform and his approach to discipline and dealing with the parents of students. Harold discusses the sense of community in Golden Meadow and how it has changed, including Cajun culture and the growth of ethnic and religious diversity. Harold discusses his, and his children's, relationship with Catholicism. He discusses the growth of auto culture, the oil industry, and chain commercial stores in the area. Harold and Louise share memories from Hurricanes Juan and Betsy and the current developments in levee construction in the region. They discuss concepts of home and community, as well as the role of boats and bridges in the bayou.
mods.note: This collection includes materials accessioned as Mss. 4700.2352. A digital version of the index (pdf) exists for duplication purposes. A digital version of the audio recording (mp3) exists for duplication purposes and public access in the Special Collections Reading Room. Interview conducted by Melissa Smith.

Harold Adams was born around 1946 in Golden Meadow, La., to Andrew Adams and Letucia Johnfroe Adams. He grew up on Bobs Lane and attended Golden Meadow School and Nicholls State University as a commuter student. He married his wife, Louise Adams, in 1969; they were both teachers. Adams taught at Golden Meadow School, returned to Nicholls to get a master's degree in guidance and psychology, then was asked to be assistant principal of Golden Meadow. A year later he was promoted to principal, a position in which he stayed until he became a supervisor with federal programs, and retired from education after 33 years. Harold and Louise Adams are practicing Catholics, have two children and a number of grandchildren.; Louise Adams was born in Larose, La., to a family of grocers. She attended Nicholls State University and was a teacher. She married Harold Adams in 1969.
